Rectifiable Curve

Posted on 2023-05-21 Edited on 2024-08-27

Curve

A curve can be conceptualized as the trace created by a moving pen on a piece of paper.
It is considered a one-dimensional object, which implies that a single number is sufficient to describe the position of a point on the curve.
More generally, in Rk\mathbb{R}^kRk, we define a curve rigorously thus.

Definition. A continuous mapping γ\gammaγ of an interval [a,b][a, b][a,b] into Rk\mathbb{R}^kRk is called a curve in Rk\mathbb{R}^kRk.

It is important to note that, under this definition, different curves may specify the same set of points, i.e. they have the same range.

Curve Length

Given a partition P={x0,…,xn}P = \{x_0 , \ldots , x_n \}P={x0​,…,xn​} of [a,b][a, b][a,b], define

Λ(P,γ)≐∑i∈[n]∥γ(xi)−γ(xi−1)∥2, \Lambda(P, \gamma) \doteq \sum_{i \in [n]} \Vert \gamma(x_i) - \gamma(x_{i - 1}) \Vert_2, Λ(P,γ)≐i∈[n]∑​∥γ(xi​)−γ(xi−1​)∥2​,

where the i(th)i^{(th)}i(th) term in the sum is the Euclidean distance between γ(xi−1)\gamma(x_{i - 1})γ(xi−1​) and γ(xi)\gamma(x_i)γ(xi​).

Therefore, Λ(P,γ)\Lambda(P, \gamma)Λ(P,γ) represents the length of a polygonal path with vertices located at γ(x0),γ(x1),…,γ(xn)\gamma(x_0), \gamma(x_1), \ldots , \gamma(x_n)γ(x0​),γ(x1​),…,γ(xn​) in order.
As the partition becomes increasingly finer, the polygon approaches the range of γ\gammaγ more closely.
Hence, it is reasonable to define the length of γ\gammaγ as

Λ(γ)≐sup⁡Λ(P,γ), \Lambda(\gamma) \doteq \sup \Lambda(P, \gamma), Λ(γ)≐supΛ(P,γ),

where the supremum is taken over all partitions of [a,b][a, b][a,b].
If Λ(γ)<∞\Lambda(\gamma) < \inftyΛ(γ)<∞, we say that γ\gammaγ is rectifiable.

Riemann Integral

In certain cases, A(γ)A( \gamma)A(γ) is given by a Riemann integral.
We shall prove this for continuously differentiable curves, i.e., for curves γ\gammaγ whose derivative γ′\gamma'γ′ is continuous.

Theorem. If γ′\gamma'γ′ is continuous on [a,b][a, b][a,b], then γ\gammaγ is rectifiable, and

Λ(γ)=∫xi−1xi∥γ′(t)∥2 dx. \Lambda(\gamma) = \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \left\Vert \gamma'(t) \right\Vert_2 \, dx. Λ(γ)=∫xi−1​xi​​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx.

Proof.
For each partition P={x0,…,xn}P = \{x_0 , \ldots , x_n \}P={x0​,…,xn​} of [a,b][a, b][a,b], we have

Λ(P,γ)=∑i∈[n]∥γ(xi)−γ(xi−1)∥2=∑i∈[n]∥∫xi−1xiγ′(t) dx∥2≤∑i∈[n]∫xi−1xi∥γ′(t)∥2 dx=∫ab∥γ′(t)∥2 dx. \begin{aligned} \Lambda(P, \gamma) &= \sum_{i \in [n]} \Vert \gamma(x_i) - \gamma(x_{i - 1}) \Vert_2 \\ &= \sum_{i \in [n]} \left\Vert \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \gamma'(t) \, dx \right\Vert_2 \le \sum_{i \in [n]} \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \left\Vert \gamma'(t) \right\Vert_2 \, dx = \int_{a}^{b} \left\Vert \gamma'(t) \right\Vert_2 \, dx . \end{aligned} Λ(P,γ)​=i∈[n]∑​∥γ(xi​)−γ(xi−1​)∥2​=i∈[n]∑​∥∥∥∥∥​∫xi−1​xi​​γ′(t)dx∥∥∥∥∥​2​≤i∈[n]∑​∫xi−1​xi​​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx=∫ab​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx.​

It follows that
Λ(γ)≤∫ab∥γ′(t)∥2 dx \Lambda(\gamma) \le \int_{a}^b \left\Vert \gamma'(t) \right\Vert_2 \, dx Λ(γ)≤∫ab​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx
and γ\gammaγ is rectifiable.

Further, since γ′\gamma'γ′ is uniformly continuous on [a,b][a, b][a,b], for each ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0, such that for each partition PPP with max⁡i∈[n](xi−xi−1)≤δ\max_{i \in [n]} (x_i - x_{i - 1}) \le \deltamaxi∈[n]​(xi​−xi−1​)≤δ, we have

∥γ′(s)−γ′(t)∥2≤ε,∀s,t∈[xi−1,xi]. \Vert \gamma'(s) - \gamma'(t) \Vert_2 \le \varepsilon, \quad \forall s, t \in [x_{i - 1}, x_i]. ∥γ′(s)−γ′(t)∥2​≤ε,∀s,t∈[xi−1​,xi​].

Hence for each i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n],

∫xi−1xi∥γ′(t)∥2 dx≤∫xi−1xi(∥γ′(xi)∥2+ε) dx=∥∫xi−1xiγ′(xi) dx∥2+∫xi−1xiε dx≤∥∫xi−1xiγ′(xi)−γ′(t) dx∥2+∥∫xi−1xiγ′(t) dx∥2+∫xi−1xiε dx≤ε⋅(xi−xi−1)+∥∫xi−1xiγ′(t) dx∥2+ε⋅(xi−xi−1)=∥γ(xi)−γ(xi−1)∥2+2ε⋅(xi−xi−1). \begin{aligned} \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \Vert \gamma'(t) \Vert_2 \, dx &\le \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \Big( \Vert \gamma'(x_i) \Vert_2 + \varepsilon \Big) \, dx \\ &= \left\Vert \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \gamma'(x_i) \, dx \right\Vert_2 + \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \varepsilon \, dx \\ &\le \left\Vert \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \gamma'(x_i) - \gamma'(t) \, dx \right\Vert_2 + \left\Vert \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \gamma'(t) \, dx \right\Vert_2 + \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \varepsilon \, dx \\ &\le \varepsilon \cdot (x_i - x_{i - 1}) + \left\Vert \int_{x_{i - 1}}^{x_i} \gamma'(t) \, dx \right\Vert_2 + \varepsilon \cdot (x_i - x_{i - 1}) \\ &= \Vert \gamma(x_i) - \gamma(x_{i - 1}) \Vert_2 + 2 \varepsilon \cdot (x_i - x_{i - 1}). \end{aligned} ∫xi−1​xi​​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx​≤∫xi−1​xi​​(∥γ′(xi​)∥2​+ε)dx=∥∥∥∥∥​∫xi−1​xi​​γ′(xi​)dx∥∥∥∥∥​2​+∫xi−1​xi​​εdx≤∥∥∥∥∥​∫xi−1​xi​​γ′(xi​)−γ′(t)dx∥∥∥∥∥​2​+∥∥∥∥∥​∫xi−1​xi​​γ′(t)dx∥∥∥∥∥​2​+∫xi−1​xi​​εdx≤ε⋅(xi​−xi−1​)+∥∥∥∥∥​∫xi−1​xi​​γ′(t)dx∥∥∥∥∥​2​+ε⋅(xi​−xi−1​)=∥γ(xi​)−γ(xi−1​)∥2​+2ε⋅(xi​−xi−1​).​

Summing over all i∈[n]i \in [n]i∈[n], we have

∫ab∥γ′(t)∥2 dx≤Λ(P,γ)+2ε(b−a)≤Λ(γ)+2ε(b−a). \int_a^b \Vert \gamma'(t) \Vert_2 \, dx \le \Lambda(P, \gamma) + 2 \varepsilon (b - a) \le \Lambda(\gamma) + 2 \varepsilon (b - a). ∫ab​∥γ′(t)∥2​dx≤Λ(P,γ)+2ε(b−a)≤Λ(γ)+2ε(b−a).

□\square□

Reference

[1] W. Rudin, Principles of mathematical analysis, 3d ed. in International series in pure and applied mathematics. New York: McGraw-Hill, 1976.

Characteristic Function

Posted on 2023-03-10 Edited on 2023-05-10

Definition

Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathcal{F}, \mathbb{P})(Ω,F,P) be a probability space, and XXX be a random variable on the space.
Further, denote μ\muμ the distribution of XXX, s.t.,

μ(A)=P(X−1(A)),∀A∈B, \begin{aligned} &\mu(A) = \mathbb{P} \Big( X^{-1}(A) \Big), &\forall A \in \mathcal{B}, \end{aligned} ​μ(A)=P(X−1(A)),​∀A∈B,​

where B\mathcal{B}B is the collection of Borel set on R\mathbb{R}R.

Definition. The characteristic function r.w.t. μ\muμ is given by

φ(t)=∫Reitx μ(dx). \varphi(t) = \int_\mathbb{R} e^{itx} \, \mu (dx) . φ(t)=∫R​eitxμ(dx).

Theorem.

φ(t)=E[eitX]. \varphi(t) = \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{itX} \right]. φ(t)=E[eitX].

Proof.
Recall that, by definition of expectation, we have

E[eitX]≐∫ΩeitX(ω) P(dω)≐∫Ω(sin⁡(tX(ω))+i⋅cos⁡(tX(ω))) P(dω)=(a)∫Rsin⁡(tx) μ(dx)+i⋅∫Rcos⁡(tx) μ(dx)=∫Reitx μ(dx)=φ(t), \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{itX} \right] &\doteq \int_\Omega e^{it X(\omega) } \, \mathbb{P} (d \omega) \\ &\doteq \int_\Omega \left( \sin \big( t X(\omega) \big) + i \cdot \cos \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right) \, \mathbb{P} (d \omega) \\ &\stackrel{(a)}{=} \int_\mathbb{R} \sin \big( t x \big) \, \mu (dx) + i \cdot \int_\mathbb{R} \cos \big( t x \big) \, \mu (d x) \\ &= \int_\mathbb{R} e^{itx} \, \mu (dx) \\ &= \varphi(t), \end{aligned} E[eitX]​≐∫Ω​eitX(ω)P(dω)≐∫Ω​(sin(tX(ω))+i⋅cos(tX(ω)))P(dω)=(a)∫R​sin(tx)μ(dx)+i⋅∫R​cos(tx)μ(dx)=∫R​eitxμ(dx)=φ(t),​

where in Equation (a)(a)(a), we have applied the fact that for each function fff that is measurable B/B\mathcal{B} / \mathcal{B}B/B,

∫Ωf(X(ω)) P(dω)=∫Rf(x) μ(dx). \int_\Omega f(X(\omega)) \, \mathbb{P}(d\omega) = \int_\mathbb{R} f(x) \, \mu(dx). ∫Ω​f(X(ω))P(dω)=∫R​f(x)μ(dx).

□\square□

Independence

Theorem. Let XXX and YYY be independent random variables.
Then

φ(X+Y)=φ(X)φ(Y). \varphi(X + Y) = \varphi(X) \varphi(Y). φ(X+Y)=φ(X)φ(Y).

Proof.
Since XXX and YYY are independent, the following pairs of random variables are independent

  1. sin⁡(tX(ω))\sin \big( t X(\omega) \big)sin(tX(ω)), sin⁡(tY(ω))\sin \big( t Y(\omega) \big)sin(tY(ω));
  2. cos⁡(tX(ω))\cos \big( t X(\omega) \big)cos(tX(ω)), cos⁡(tY(ω))\cos \big( t Y(\omega) \big)cos(tY(ω));
  3. sin⁡(tX(ω))\sin \big( t X(\omega) \big)sin(tX(ω)), cos⁡(tY(ω))\cos \big( t Y(\omega) \big)cos(tY(ω));
  4. cos⁡(tX(ω))\cos \big( t X(\omega) \big)cos(tX(ω)), sin⁡(tY(ω))\sin \big( t Y(\omega) \big)sin(tY(ω)).

φ(X+Y)=E[eit(X+Y)]=E[(sin⁡(tX(ω))+i⋅cos⁡(tX(ω)))(sin⁡(tY(ω))+i⋅cos⁡(tY(ω)))]=E[sin⁡(tX(ω))]E[sin⁡(tY(ω))]−E[cos⁡(tX(ω))]E[cos⁡(tY(ω))]+iE[sin⁡(tX(ω))]E[cos⁡(tY(ω))]+iE[cos⁡(tX(ω))]E[sin⁡(tY(ω))]=φ(X)φ(Y). \begin{aligned} \varphi(X + Y) &= \mathbb{E} \left[ e^{it(X + Y)} \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \left( \sin \big( t X(\omega) \big) + i \cdot \cos \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right) \left( \sin \big( t Y(\omega) \big) + i \cdot \cos \big( t Y(\omega) \big) \right) \right] \\ &= \mathbb{E} \left[ \sin \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right] \mathbb{E} \left[ \sin \big( t Y(\omega) \big) \right] - \mathbb{E} \left[ \cos \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right] \mathbb{E} \left[ \cos \big( t Y(\omega) \big) \right] \\ &\qquad + i \mathbb{E} \left[ \sin \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right] \mathbb{E} \left[ \cos \big( t Y(\omega) \big) \right] + i \mathbb{E} \left[ \cos \big( t X(\omega) \big) \right] \mathbb{E} \left[ \sin \big( t Y(\omega) \big) \right] \\ &= \varphi(X) \varphi(Y). \end{aligned} φ(X+Y)​=E[eit(X+Y)]=E[(sin(tX(ω))+i⋅cos(tX(ω)))(sin(tY(ω))+i⋅cos(tY(ω)))]=E[sin(tX(ω))]E[sin(tY(ω))]−E[cos(tX(ω))]E[cos(tY(ω))]+iE[sin(tX(ω))]E[cos(tY(ω))]+iE[cos(tX(ω))]E[sin(tY(ω))]=φ(X)φ(Y).​

□\square□

Uniqueness

Theorem. Let μ\muμ and ν\nuν be probability measures on R\mathbb{R}R.
If μ\muμ and ν\nuν has the same characteristic functions, then

μ(A)=ν(A),∀A∈B. \begin{aligned} &\mu(A) = \nu(A), &\forall A \in \mathcal{B}. \end{aligned} ​μ(A)=ν(A),​∀A∈B.​

The proof follows from the following lemma:

Lemma. Let a,b∈Ra, b \in \mathbb{R}a,b∈R, s.t. a<ba < ba<b.
If μ({a})=μ({b})=0\mu(\{a\}) = \mu(\{b\}) = 0μ({a})=μ({b})=0, then

μ((a,b])=lim⁡T→∞12π∫−TTe−ita−e−itbitφ(t) dt. \mu \Big( (a, b] \Big) = \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-T}^T \frac{e^{-ita} - e^{-itb}}{it} \varphi(t) \, d t. μ((a,b])=T→∞lim​2π1​∫−TT​ite−ita−e−itb​φ(t)dt.

Proof of the Theorem.
For each n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}_+n∈N+​, define En≐{x∈R:μ({x})≥1/n}E_n \doteq \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : \mu( \{ x \} ) \ge 1 / n \}En​≐{x∈R:μ({x})≥1/n}.
It is easy to see that ∣En∣≤n|E_n| \le n∣En​∣≤n.
It follows that the E≐∪n∈N+EnE \doteq \cup_{n \in \mathbb{N}_+} E_nE≐∪n∈N+​​En​ is countable.

Consider the set S={(a,b]:a<b,μ({a})=μ({b})=0}S = \{ (a, b] : a < b, \mu(\{a\}) = \mu(\{b\}) = 0 \}S={(a,b]:a<b,μ({a})=μ({b})=0}.
Obviously this is a π\piπ system.
Further, it generates B\mathcal{B}B.
To see this, for each point c∈Ec \in Ec∈E, we can find

  1. a sequence a1,a2,…a_1, a_2, \ldotsa1​,a2​,… from Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ that increases to ccc,
  2. a sequence b1,b2,…b_1, b_2, \ldotsb1​,b2​,… from Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ that decreases to ccc.

Then (ai,bi]∈S(a_i, b_i] \in S(ai​,bi​]∈S, and ∩i≥1(ai,bi]=[c,c]\cap_{i \ge 1} (a_i, b_i] = [c, c]∩i≥1​(ai​,bi​]=[c,c].

It follows that every interval (a,b]⊆R(a, b] \subseteq \mathbb{R}(a,b]⊆R can be generated by intervals in SSS.

According to the lemma, μ\muμ and ν\nuν agrees on a π\piπ system that generates B\mathcal{B}B.
By π\piπ-λ\lambdaλ theorem, they agree on each set in B\mathcal{B}B.

□\square□

Proof of the Lemma.
We are going to prove that, for each a<ba < ba<b,

lim⁡T→∞12π∫−TTe−ita−e−itbitφ(t) dt=μ(a,b)+μ({a,b}). \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-T}^T \frac{e^{-ita} - e^{-itb}}{it} \varphi(t) \, d t = \mu(a, b) + \mu \big( \{a, b \} \big). T→∞lim​2π1​∫−TT​ite−ita−e−itb​φ(t)dt=μ(a,b)+μ({a,b}).

Define

IT≐∫−TTe−ita−e−itbitφ(t) dt=∫−TT∫Re−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)it μ(dx) dt=(a)∫R∫−TTe−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)it dt μ(dx)=(b)∫R∫−TT[sin⁡((x−a)t)t−sin⁡((x−b)t)t] dt μ(dx)=(c)2∫R∫0T[sin⁡((x−a)t)t−sin⁡((x−b)t)t] dt μ(dx) \begin{aligned} I_T &\doteq \int_{-T}^T \frac{e^{-ita} - e^{-itb}}{it} \varphi(t) \, d t \\ &= \int_{-T}^T \int_\mathbb{R} \frac{e^{-it(a - x)} - e^{-it(b - x)}}{it} \,\mu(dx) \, d t \\ &\stackrel{(a)}{=} \int_\mathbb{R} \int_{-T}^T \frac{e^{-it(a - x)} - e^{-it(b - x)}}{it} \, d t \, \mu(dx) \\ &\stackrel{(b)}{=} \int_\mathbb{R} \int_{-T}^T \left[ \frac{\sin \big( (x - a) t \big) }{t} - \frac{\sin \big( (x - b) t \big) }{t} \right] \, d t \, \mu(dx) \\ &\stackrel{(c)}{=} 2 \int_\mathbb{R} \int_{0}^T \left[ \frac{\sin \big( (x - a) t \big) }{t} - \frac{\sin \big( (x - b) t \big) }{t} \right] \, d t \, \mu(dx) \end{aligned} IT​​≐∫−TT​ite−ita−e−itb​φ(t)dt=∫−TT​∫R​ite−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)​μ(dx)dt=(a)∫R​∫−TT​ite−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)​dtμ(dx)=(b)∫R​∫−TT​[tsin((x−a)t)​−tsin((x−b)t)​]dtμ(dx)=(c)2∫R​∫0T​[tsin((x−a)t)​−tsin((x−b)t)​]dtμ(dx)​

where

  • Equation (a)(a)(a) holds: since e−ix=1+∫0xe−is dse^{-i x} = 1 + \int_0^x e^{-is} \, d se−ix=1+∫0x​e−isds,

    ∣e−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)it∣=∣∫(b−x)(a−x)e−is ds∣≤∣b−a∣ \begin{aligned} \left| \frac{e^{-it(a - x)} - e^{-it(b - x)}}{it} \right| = \left| \int_{(b - x)}^{(a - x)} e^{-is} \, d s \right| \le |b - a| \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​ite−it(a−x)−e−it(b−x)​∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣∣​∫(b−x)(a−x)​e−isds∣∣∣∣∣∣​≤∣b−a∣​

    is therefore bounded.
    Hence, by Fubini’s theorem, we can exchange the order of the double integral over finite product measure.

  • Equation (b)(b)(b) holds: since cos⁡((x−a)t)/(it)\cos \big( (x - a) t \big) / (it)cos((x−a)t)/(it) and cos⁡((x−b)t)/(it)\cos \big( (x - b) t \big) / (it)cos((x−b)t)/(it) are odd functions over [−T,T][-T, T][−T,T]

  • Equation (c)(c)(c) holds: since sin⁡((x−a)t)/(it)\sin \big( (x - a) t \big) / (it)sin((x−a)t)/(it) and sin⁡((x−b)t)/(it)\sin \big( (x - b) t \big) / (it)sin((x−b)t)/(it) are even functions over [−T,T][-T, T][−T,T]

Next, define S(T)≐∫0Tsin⁡xx dxS(T) \doteq \int_0^T \tfrac{\sin x}{x} \, dxS(T)≐∫0T​xsinx​dx.
Introducing the function

sgn(θ)={1, if  θ>0,0, if  θ=0,−1, if  θ<0, \mathsf{sgn}(\theta) = \begin{cases} 1, &\text{ if }\, \theta > 0, \\ 0, &\text{ if }\, \theta = 0, \\ -1, &\text{ if }\, \theta < 0, \end{cases} sgn(θ)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​1,0,−1,​ if θ>0, if θ=0, if θ<0,​

we can write

R(θ,T)≐∫0Tsin⁡θxx dx=sgn(θ)⋅S(∣θ∣T). R(\theta, T) \doteq \int_0^T \frac{\sin \theta x}{x} \, dx = \mathsf{sgn}(\theta) \cdot S(|\theta| T). R(θ,T)≐∫0T​xsinθx​dx=sgn(θ)⋅S(∣θ∣T).

Since T→∞{T \rightarrow \infty}T→∞, S(T)→π/2S(T) \rightarrow \pi / 2S(T)→π/2, we have R(θ,T)→sgn(θ)⋅π/2R(\theta, T) \rightarrow \mathsf{sgn}(\theta) \cdot \pi / 2R(θ,T)→sgn(θ)⋅π/2.
Hence,

lim⁡T→∞{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)}={0,x<a,π/2,x=a,π,a<x<b,π/2,x=b,0,x>b. \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \Big\{ R(x - a, T) - R(x - b, T) \Big\} = \begin{cases} 0, & x < a, \\ \pi / 2, & x = a, \\ \pi, & a < x < b, \\ \pi / 2, & x = b, \\ 0, & x > b. \end{cases} T→∞lim​{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)}=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​0,π/2,π,π/2,0,​x<a,x=a,a<x<b,x=b,x>b.​

Finally, ∣R(θ,T)∣=∣S(∣θ∣T)∣≤sup⁡tS(t)<∞|R(\theta, T)| = \Big| S \big( |\theta| T \big) \Big| \le \sup_t S(t) < \infty∣R(θ,T)∣=∣∣∣∣​S(∣θ∣T)∣∣∣∣​≤supt​S(t)<∞, by bounded convergence theorem,

lim⁡T→∞IT=2lim⁡T→∞∫R∫0T[sin⁡((x−a)t)t−sin⁡((x−b)t)t] dt μ(dx)=2lim⁡T→∞∫R{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)} μ(dx)=2∫Rlim⁡T→∞{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)} μ(dx)=2π⋅μ(a,b)+πμ({a,b}), \begin{aligned} \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} I_T &= 2 \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \int_\mathbb{R} \int_{0}^T \left[ \frac{\sin \big( (x - a) t \big) }{t} - \frac{\sin \big( (x - b) t \big) }{t} \right] \, d t \, \mu(dx) \\ &= 2 \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \int_\mathbb{R} \Big\{ R(x - a, T) - R(x - b, T) \Big\} \, \mu(dx) \\ &= 2 \int_\mathbb{R} \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} \Big\{ R(x - a, T) - R(x - b, T) \Big\} \, \mu(dx) \\ &= 2 \pi \cdot \mu (a, b) + \pi \mu (\{a, b\}), \end{aligned} T→∞lim​IT​​=2T→∞lim​∫R​∫0T​[tsin((x−a)t)​−tsin((x−b)t)​]dtμ(dx)=2T→∞lim​∫R​{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)}μ(dx)=2∫R​T→∞lim​{R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)}μ(dx)=2π⋅μ(a,b)+πμ({a,b}),​

which concludes the proof.

Remark.
Here, let fT(x)≐R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T)f_T(x) \doteq R(x - a, T) - R(x - b, T)fT​(x)≐R(x−a,T)−R(x−b,T), and f(x)≐lim⁡T→∞fT(x)f(x) \doteq \lim_{T \rightarrow \infty} f_T(x)f(x)≐limT→∞​fT​(x).
Since fT(x)f_T(x)fT​(x) is bounded, assume that ∣fT(x)∣≤B,∀x,T|f_T(x)| \le B, \forall x, T∣fT​(x)∣≤B,∀x,T.

Let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0.
For each T∈R+T \in \mathbb{R}^+T∈R+, define ET≐{x∈R:∣fT(x)−f(x)∣≤ϵ}E_T \doteq \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : | f_T(x) - f(x) | \le \epsilon \}ET​≐{x∈R:∣fT​(x)−f(x)∣≤ϵ}.
Then

∣∫RfT(x)−f(x) μ(dx)∣≤∫R∣fT(x)−f(x)∣ μ(dx)=∫ET∣fT(x)−f(x)∣ μ(dx)+∫ET‾∣fT(x)−f(x)∣ μ(dx)≤ϵ+2B⋅μ(ET‾). \begin{aligned} \left| \int_\mathbb{R} f_T(x) - f(x) \, \mu (dx) \right| &\le \int_\mathbb{R} \left| f_T(x) - f(x) \right|\, \mu (dx) \\ &= \int_{E_T} \left| f_T(x) - f(x) \right|\, \mu (dx) + \int_{\overline{E_T}} \left| f_T(x) - f(x) \right| \, \mu (dx) \\ &\le \epsilon + 2B \cdot \mu \Big( \overline{E_T} \Big). \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫R​fT​(x)−f(x)μ(dx)∣∣∣∣∣​​≤∫R​∣fT​(x)−f(x)∣μ(dx)=∫ET​​∣fT​(x)−f(x)∣μ(dx)+∫ET​​​∣fT​(x)−f(x)∣μ(dx)≤ϵ+2B⋅μ(ET​​).​

Finally, for x∉(a−ϵ,a+ϵ)∪(b−ϵ,b+ϵ)x \notin (a - \epsilon, a + \epsilon) \cup (b - \epsilon, b + \epsilon)x∈/(a−ϵ,a+ϵ)∪(b−ϵ,b+ϵ), we have ∣x−a∣T,∣x−b∣T≥ϵT|x - a| T, |x - b| T \ge \epsilon T∣x−a∣T,∣x−b∣T≥ϵT.
Hence,

∣fT(x)−f(x)∣≤2⋅∣S(ϵT)−S(∞)∣, |f_T(x) - f(x)| \le 2 \cdot \left| S(\epsilon T) - S(\infty)\right|, ∣fT​(x)−f(x)∣≤2⋅∣S(ϵT)−S(∞)∣,

which approaches 000 as T→∞T \rightarrow \inftyT→∞.
So

∣∫RfT(x)−f(x) μ(dx)∣→(1+2B)⋅ϵ. \begin{aligned} \left| \int_\mathbb{R} f_T(x) - f(x) \, \mu (dx) \right| \rightarrow (1 + 2B) \cdot \epsilon. \end{aligned} ∣∣∣∣∣​∫R​fT​(x)−f(x)μ(dx)∣∣∣∣∣​→(1+2B)⋅ϵ.​

□\square□

Reference

Multivariate Fubini's Theorem

Posted on 2022-12-25 Edited on 2023-02-04

Let k∈N+k \in \mathbb{N}^+k∈N+, k≥2k \ge 2k≥2, and (Ωi,Fi,μi),i∈[k](\Omega_{i}, \mathcal{F}_i, \mu_i), i \in [k](Ωi​,Fi​,μi​),i∈[k] be σ\sigmaσ-finite measure spaces.

Product Measure Space

Consider the product space Ω=×i∈[k]Ωi\Omega = \times_{i \in [k]} \Omega_{i}Ω=×i∈[k]​Ωi​.

Definition. A measurable rectangle is a product ×i∈[k]Ai\times_{i \in [k]} A_i×i∈[k]​Ai​ for which Ai∈Fi,i∈[k]A_i \in \mathcal{F}_i, i \in [k]Ai​∈Fi​,i∈[k].

Denote the collection of measurable rectangles as

S≐{×i∈[k]Ai,Ai∈Fi,∀i∈[k]}. \mathcal{S} \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} \times_{i \in [k]} A_i, A_i \in \mathcal{F}_i, \forall i \in [k] \end{Bmatrix}. S≐{×i∈[k]​Ai​,Ai​∈Fi​,∀i∈[k]​}.

Let ×i∈[k]Fi≐σ(S)\times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i \doteq \sigma(\mathcal{S})×i∈[k]​Fi​≐σ(S) be the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by S\mathcal{S}S.
Following similar vein, for each I⊆[k]I \subseteq [k]I⊆[k], we can define ×i∈IFi\times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i×i∈I​Fi​ to be the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by measurable rectangles {×i∈IAi,Ai∈Fi,∀i∈I}\{ \times_{i \in I} A_i, A_i \in \mathcal{F}_i, \forall i \in I \}{×i∈I​Ai​,Ai​∈Fi​,∀i∈I}.

We would like to construct a measure μ\muμ on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S), thus

  1. For each ×i∈[k]Ai∈S\times_{i \in [k]} A_i \in \mathcal{S}×i∈[k]​Ai​∈S, it’s natural to define μ(×i∈[k]Ai)=∏i∈[k]μi(Ai)\mu (\times_{i \in [k]} A_i) = \prod_{i \in [k]} \mu_i(A_i)μ(×i∈[k]​Ai​)=∏i∈[k]​μi​(Ai​).

  2. We prove that S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

  3. We show that μ\muμ is a measure on S\mathcal{S}S.

  4. Finally, it follows by the Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem, μ\muμ has a unique extension on σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S).

Lemma 1. S\mathcal{S}S is a semialgebra.

Proof.

  • S\mathcal{S}S is close under intersection: if ×i∈[k]Ai,×i∈[k]Bi∈S\times_{i \in [k]} A_i, \times_{i \in [k]} B_i \in \mathcal{S}×i∈[k]​Ai​,×i∈[k]​Bi​∈S, then

    (×i∈[k]Ai)∩(×i∈[k]Bi)=×i∈[k](Ai∩Bi). (\times_{i \in [k]} A_i) \cap (\times_{i \in [k]} B_i) = \times_{i \in [k]} (A_i \cap B_i). (×i∈[k]​Ai​)∩(×i∈[k]​Bi​)=×i∈[k]​(Ai​∩Bi​).

  • The complement of element in S\mathcal{S}S is a finite disjoint union of elements in S\mathcal{S}S: if ×i∈[k]Ai∈S\times_{i \in [k]} A_i \in \mathcal{S}×i∈[k]​Ai​∈S, since

    Ω=×i∈[k](Ai+Aiˉ), \Omega = \times_{i \in [k]} \big( A_i +\bar{A_i} \big), Ω=×i∈[k]​(Ai​+Ai​ˉ​),

    it holds that

    ×i∈[k]Ai‾=∑(×i∈[k]Bi), \overline{ \times_{i \in [k]} A_i } = \sum \big( \times_{i \in [k]} B_i \big), ×i∈[k]​Ai​​=∑(×i∈[k]​Bi​),

    where Bi=AiB_i = A_iBi​=Ai​ or Bi=AiˉB_i = \bar{A_i}Bi​=Ai​ˉ​, and ×i∈[k]Bi≠∑i∈[k]Ai\times_{i \in [k]} B_i \neq \sum_{i \in [k]} A_i×i∈[k]​Bi​=∑i∈[k]​Ai​.

□\square□

Theorem. There is a unique extension μ\muμ, that is a measure on σ(S)\sigma( \mathcal{S} )σ(S).

Proof.
We prove the theorem by induction.
For each ℓ∈[k]\ell \in [k]ℓ∈[k], define

S1:ℓ≐{×i∈[ℓ]Ai,Ai∈Fi,∀i∈[ℓ]}, \mathcal{S}_{1:\ell} \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} \times_{i \in [\ell]} A_i, A_i \in \mathcal{F}_i, \forall i \in [\ell] \end{Bmatrix}, S1:ℓ​≐{×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​,Ai​∈Fi​,∀i∈[ℓ]​},

and

μ1:ℓ(×i∈[ℓ]Ai)=∏i∈[ℓ]μi(Ai). \mu_{1:\ell} (\times_{i \in [\ell]} A_i) = \prod_{i \in [\ell]} \mu_i(A_i). μ1:ℓ​(×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​)=i∈[ℓ]∏​μi​(Ai​).

Our goal is to show that μ1:ℓ\mu_{1:\ell}μ1:ℓ​ is a σ\sigmaσ-finite measure on S1:ℓ\mathcal{S}_{1:\ell}S1:ℓ​.
Note that S1:ℓ\mathcal{S}_{1:\ell}S1:ℓ​ is a semialgebra and μ\muμ is a σ1:ℓ\sigma_{1:\ell}σ1:ℓ​-finite measure.
Applying
Caratheodory’s Extension Theorem, we see that there is a unique extension μ1:ℓ\mu_{1:\ell}μ1:ℓ​ of μ1:ℓ\mu_{1:\ell}μ1:ℓ​, that is a measure on σ(S1:ℓ)\sigma( \mathcal{S}_{1:\ell} )σ(S1:ℓ​).

The claim clearly holds for ℓ=1\ell = 1ℓ=1.

Next, we prove that if the claim holds for ℓ<k\ell < kℓ<k, then it holds for ℓ+1\ell + 1ℓ+1.
The σ\sigmaσ-finiteness follows directly from the finiteness of μ1,…,μℓ+1\mu_1, \ldots, \mu_{\ell + 1}μ1​,…,μℓ+1​.
It suffices to prove σ\sigmaσ-additivity of μ1:ℓ+1\mu_{1 : \ell + 1}μ1:ℓ+1​.

Suppose ×i∈[ℓ+1]Ai=+m≥1(×i∈[ℓ+1]Bm,i)\times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} A_i = +_{m \ge 1} (\times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} B_{m, i})×i∈[ℓ+1]​Ai​=+m≥1​(×i∈[ℓ+1]​Bm,i​) is a countable disjoint union of elements in S1:ℓ+1\mathcal{S}_{1: \ell + 1}S1:ℓ+1​.

Consider an x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Aix_{1 : \ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} A_ix1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​.
For each xℓ+1∈Aℓ+1x_{\ell + 1} \in A_{\ell + 1}xℓ+1​∈Aℓ+1​, we have (x1,…,xℓ+1)∈×i∈[ℓ+1]Ai(x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell + 1}) \in \times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} A_i(x1​,…,xℓ+1​)∈×i∈[ℓ+1]​Ai​.
As the sets {×i∈[ℓ+1]Bm,i}\begin{Bmatrix} \times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} B_{m, i} \end{Bmatrix}{×i∈[ℓ+1]​Bm,i​​} consists of a partition of ×i∈[ℓ+1]Ai\times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} A_i×i∈[ℓ+1]​Ai​, it follows that (x1,…,xℓ+1)(x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell + 1})(x1​,…,xℓ+1​) belongs to exactly one ×i∈[ℓ+1]Bm,i\times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} B_{m, i}×i∈[ℓ+1]​Bm,i​.
Denote

I(x1:ℓ)≐{m:∃xℓ+1∈Bm,ℓ+1, s.t., (x1,…,xℓ+1)∈×i∈[ℓ+1]Bm,i}={m:x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Bm,i}. \begin{aligned} I(x_{1:\ell}) &\doteq \begin{Bmatrix} m : \exists x_{\ell + 1} \in B_{m,\ell + 1},\, \text{s.t.},\, (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell + 1}) \in \times_{i \in [\ell + 1]} B_{m, i} \end{Bmatrix} \\ &= \begin{Bmatrix} m : x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} B_{m, i} \end{Bmatrix}. \end{aligned} I(x1:ℓ​)​≐{m:∃xℓ+1​∈Bm,ℓ+1​,s.t.,(x1​,…,xℓ+1​)∈×i∈[ℓ+1]​Bm,i​​}={m:x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Bm,i​​}.​

Then Aℓ+1=+m∈I(x)Bm,ℓ+1A_{\ell + 1} = +_{m \in I(x)} B_{m, \ell + 1}Aℓ+1​=+m∈I(x)​Bm,ℓ+1​.

As μℓ+1\mu_{\ell + 1}μℓ+1​ is a measure on (Ωℓ+1,Fℓ+1)(\Omega_{\ell + 1}, \mathcal{F}_{\ell + 1})(Ωℓ+1​,Fℓ+1​), it is countably additive:

I[x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Ai]⋅μℓ+1(Aℓ+1)=∑m∈I(x1:ℓ)μℓ+1(Bm,ℓ+1)  ⟹  I[x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Ai]⋅μℓ+1(Aℓ+1)=∑m≥1I[x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Bm,i]⋅μℓ+1(Bℓ+1). \begin{aligned} &\mathbb{I} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell ]} A_i \end{bmatrix} \cdot \mu_{\ell + 1} (A_{\ell + 1}) = \sum_{m \in I(x_{1:\ell}) } \mu_{\ell + 1} (B_{m, \ell + 1}) \\ \implies &\mathbb{I} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} A_i \end{bmatrix} \cdot \mu_{\ell + 1} (A_{\ell + 1}) = \sum_{m \ge 1} \mathbb{I} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} B_{m, i} \end{bmatrix} \cdot \mu_{\ell + 1} (B_{\ell + 1}). \end{aligned} ⟹​I[x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​​]⋅μℓ+1​(Aℓ+1​)=m∈I(x1:ℓ​)∑​μℓ+1​(Bm,ℓ+1​)I[x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​​]⋅μℓ+1​(Aℓ+1​)=m≥1∑​I[x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Bm,i​​]⋅μℓ+1​(Bℓ+1​).​

By monotone convergence theorem,

∫×i∈[ℓ]ΩiI[x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Ai]⋅μℓ+1(Aℓ+1) d (μ1:ℓ)=∑m≥1∫×i∈[ℓ]ΩiI[x1:ℓ∈×i∈[ℓ]Bm,i]⋅μℓ+1(Bℓ+1) d (μ1:ℓ) \begin{aligned} &\int_{\times_{i \in [\ell]} \Omega_{i}} \mathbb{I} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} A_i \end{bmatrix} \cdot \mu_{\ell + 1} (A_{\ell + 1}) \, d\, \big( \mu_{1:\ell} \big) \\ = &\sum_{m \ge 1} \int_{\times_{i \in [\ell]} \Omega_{i}} \mathbb{I} \begin{bmatrix} x_{1:\ell} \in \times_{i \in [\ell]} B_{m, i} \end{bmatrix} \cdot \mu_{\ell + 1} (B_{\ell + 1}) \, d\, \big( \mu_{1:\ell} \big) \\ \end{aligned} =​∫×i∈[ℓ]​Ωi​​I[x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Ai​​]⋅μℓ+1​(Aℓ+1​)d(μ1:ℓ​)m≥1∑​∫×i∈[ℓ]​Ωi​​I[x1:ℓ​∈×i∈[ℓ]​Bm,i​​]⋅μℓ+1​(Bℓ+1​)d(μ1:ℓ​)​

which is

μ1(A1)⋯μℓ+1(Aℓ+1)=∑i≥1μ1(Bm,1)⋯μℓ+1(Bm,ℓ+1). \mu_1(A_1) \cdots \mu_{\ell + 1} (A_{\ell + 1}) = \sum_{i \ge 1} \mu_1(B_{m, 1}) \cdots \mu_{\ell + 1} (B_{m, \ell + 1}). μ1​(A1​)⋯μℓ+1​(Aℓ+1​)=i≥1∑​μ1​(Bm,1​)⋯μℓ+1​(Bm,ℓ+1​).

□\square□

An Interesting Property

Define the operation ordered product ×⃗\vec{\times}×​ on two measurable set A∈(×i∈IFi)A \in \left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right)A∈(×i∈I​Fi​) and B∈(×i∈I‾Fi)B \in \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right)B∈(×i∈I​Fi​) as

A×⃗B≐{(x1,…,xk):xi∈A,∀i∈Ixi∈B,∀i∈I‾}, A \vec{\times} B \doteq \begin{Bmatrix} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) : \begin{matrix} x_i \in A, \forall i \in I \\ x_i \in B, \forall i \in \overline{I} \end{matrix} \end{Bmatrix}, A×​B≐{(x1​,…,xk​):xi​∈A,∀i∈Ixi​∈B,∀i∈I​​},

and let (×i∈IFi)×⃗(×i∈I‾Fi)\left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right)(×i∈I​Fi​)×​(×i∈I​Fi​) to be the σ\sigmaσ-field generated by measurable rectangles

SI,I‾≐{A×⃗B,A∈(×i∈IFi),B∈(×i∈I‾Fi)}. \mathcal{S}_{I, \overline{I}} \doteq \left\{ A \vec{\times} B, A \in \left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right), B \in \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \right\}. SI,I​≐{A×​B,A∈(×i∈I​Fi​),B∈(×i∈I​Fi​)}.

Theorem. Let I⊆[k]I \subseteq [k]I⊆[k], and consider

(×i∈IFi)×⃗(×i∈I‾Fi)=×i∈[k]Fi \left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right) = \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i (×i∈I​Fi​)×​(×i∈I​Fi​)=×i∈[k]​Fi​

Proof.
Since S⊆SI,I‾\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{S}_{I, \overline{I}}S⊆SI,I​, clearly it holds that

×i∈[k]Fi⊆(×i∈IFi)×⃗(×i∈I‾Fi). \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i \subseteq \left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right). ×i∈[k]​Fi​⊆(×i∈I​Fi​)×​(×i∈I​Fi​).

On the other hand, for each A×⃗B∈SI,I‾A \vec{\times} B \in \mathcal{S}_{I, \overline{I}}A×​B∈SI,I​, we claim that A×⃗B∈×i∈[k]FiA \vec{\times} B \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_iA×​B∈×i∈[k]​Fi​.
Hence ×i∈[k]Fi\times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i×i∈[k]​Fi​ is a σ\sigmaσ-field containing SI,I‾\mathcal{S}_{I, \overline{I}}SI,I​.
Via the definition of (×i∈IFi)×⃗(×i∈I‾Fi)\left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right)(×i∈I​Fi​)×​(×i∈I​Fi​), we conclude that

(×i∈IFi)×⃗(×i∈I‾Fi)⊆×i∈[k]Fi. \left( \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I}} \mathcal{F}_i \right) \subseteq \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i. (×i∈I​Fi​)×​(×i∈I​Fi​)⊆×i∈[k]​Fi​.

To prove the claim, we will show A×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi)∈×i∈[k]FiA \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_iA×​(×i∈I​Ωi​)∈×i∈[k]​Fi​ and (×i∈IΩi)×⃗B∈×i∈[k]Fi\left( \times_{i \in I } \Omega_{i} \right) \vec{\times} B \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i(×i∈I​Ωi​)×​B∈×i∈[k]​Fi​.
By symmetry, we need only to prove the former.

Consider

L×i∈IΩi≐{AI:AI×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi)∈×i∈[k]Fi} \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}} \doteq \{ A_I : A_I \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i \} L×i∈I​Ωi​​≐{AI​:AI​×​(×i∈I​Ωi​)∈×i∈[k]​Fi​}

Then SI∈L×i∈IΩi\mathcal{S}_I \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}SI​∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​.
Further,

  1. ∅∈L×i∈IΩi\emptyset \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}∅∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​;

  2. If AI∈L×i∈IΩiA_I \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}AI​∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​, then AˉI∈L×i∈IΩi\bar A_I \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}AˉI​∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​, as AˉI×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi)∈×i∈[k]Fi\bar A_I \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_iAˉI​×​(×i∈I​Ωi​)∈×i∈[k]​Fi​

  3. If AI(n)∈L×i∈IΩiA_I^{(n)} \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}AI(n)​∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​ for n∈N+n \in \mathbb{N}^+n∈N+, then ∪n≥1AI(n)∈L×i∈IΩi\cup_{n \ge 1} A_I^{(n)} \in \mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}∪n≥1​AI(n)​∈L×i∈I​Ωi​​, as

    (∪n≥1AI(n))×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi)=∪n≥1(AI(n)×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi))∈×i∈[k]Fi \left( \cup_{n \ge 1} A_I^{(n)} \right) \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) = \cup_{n \ge 1} \left( A_I^{(n)} \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) \right) \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_i (∪n≥1​AI(n)​)×​(×i∈I​Ωi​)=∪n≥1​(AI(n)​×​(×i∈I​Ωi​))∈×i∈[k]​Fi​

It follows that L×i∈IΩi\mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}}L×i∈I​Ωi​​ is a σ\sigmaσ-field, and therefore L×i∈IΩi⊇×i∈IFi\mathcal{L}_{\times_{i \in I} \Omega_{i}} \supseteq \times_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_iL×i∈I​Ωi​​⊇×i∈I​Fi​.
It concludes that A×⃗(×i∈I‾Ωi)∈×i∈[k]FiA \vec{\times} \left( \times_{i \in \overline{I} } \Omega_{i} \right) \in \times_{i \in [k]} \mathcal{F}_iA×​(×i∈I​Ωi​)∈×i∈[k]​Fi​.

□\square□

Fubini’s Theorem

Integration is a generalization of discrete sum.
Given a measure space (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​), and a measure function fff, the integral of fff exists, if

  1. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0;
  2. Or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞.

In case that (Ω,σ(S),μˉ)(\Omega, \sigma( \mathcal{S} ), \bar \mu)(Ω,σ(S),μˉ​) is a produce measure space, the Fubini’s theorem states that if the integral exists, it can be computed by iterated integrals.

Theorem (Fubini’s Theorem). If f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 or ∫∣f∣d μˉ<∞\int |f| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫∣f∣dμˉ​<∞, then there exists Ai∈Fi,i∈[k]A_i \in \mathcal{F}_i, i \in [k]Ai​∈Fi​,i∈[k], s.t., μi(Ai)=0\mu_i (A_i) = 0μi​(Ai​)=0, and for each permutation π\piπ of [k][k][k],

∫Ωf(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ωπ(1)−Aπ(1)…∫Ωπ(k−1)−Aπ(k−1)∫Ωπ(k)f(x1,…,xk)d μπ(k) …d μπ(1). \int_{\Omega } f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu = \int_{\Omega_{\pi(1)} - A_{\pi(1)}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{\pi(k - 1)} - A_{\pi(k - 1)}} \int_{\Omega_{\pi(k)}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{\pi(k)} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{\pi(1)}. ∫Ω​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ωπ(1)​−Aπ(1)​​…∫Ωπ(k−1)​−Aπ(k−1)​​∫Ωπ(k)​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμπ(k)​…dμπ(1)​.

Remark. For the case concerning f≥0f \ge 0f≥0, we have Ai=∅,i∈[k]A_i = \emptyset, i \in [k]Ai​=∅,i∈[k], and the Theorem is called Tonelli’s theorem.

Proof of Fubini’s Theorem

By symmetry, it suffices to prove that

∫Ωf(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ω1−A1…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1. \int_{\Omega } f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu = \int_{\Omega_{1} - A_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1}. ∫Ω​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω1​−A1​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​.

Sketch of the Proof

Before proving that the iterated integral equals the double integral, we need to make sure that the first iterated integral is well-defined.
Specifically,

  • When x1:k−1x_{1 : k - 1}x1:k−1​ is fixed, the function fx1:k−1:Ωk→Rf_{x_{1:k - 1}} : \Omega_{k} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}fx1:k−1​​:Ωk​→R defined by fx1:k−1(xk)≐f(x1,…,xk)f_{x_{1:k - 1}}(x_k) \doteq f(x_1, \ldots, x_k)fx1:k−1​​(xk​)≐f(x1​,…,xk​) is Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable, and the integral ∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk) d μk\int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_k∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​ exists.

  • For each ℓ∈[k−1]\ell \in [k - 1]ℓ∈[k−1], there is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable function gℓ:Ωℓ→Rg_\ell : \Omega_{\ell} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}gℓ​:Ωℓ​→R such that

gℓ(xℓ)=∫Ωℓ+1−Aℓ+1…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk) d μk … d μℓ+1,a.e.. g_\ell (x_\ell) = \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1} - A_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1}, \qquad a.e.. gℓ​(xℓ​)=∫Ωℓ+1​−Aℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​,a.e..

We will first establish the theorem for indicator functions IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ for sets E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), which serves as a basic building blocks for extending the theorem for more general functions.

Lemma. Given E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma( \mathcal{S} )E∈σ(S), let IE\mathbb{I}_EIE​ be the indicator for (x1,…,xk)∈E(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \in E(x1​,…,xk​)∈E. Then

  1. For each xk∈Ωkx_k \in \Omega_{k}xk​∈Ωk​, the function fx1:k−1(xk)≐IE(x1,…,xk)f_{x_{1:k - 1}}(x_k) \doteq \mathbb{I}_E (x_1, \ldots, x_k)fx1:k−1​​(xk​)≐IE​(x1​,…,xk​) is Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable.

  2. The function gℓ(xℓ)≐∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIE(x1,…,xk) d μk … d μℓ+1g_\ell (x_\ell) \doteq \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_E (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1}gℓ​(xℓ​)≐∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IE​(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​ is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_{\ell}Fℓ​ measurable.

  3. ∫ΩIE(x1,…,xk) d μˉ=∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIE(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1. \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_E (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \bar \mu = \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_E (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1}. ∫Ω​IE​(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IE​(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​.

The proof of the lemma is relegated to the end of the article.

Proof of the Theorem

For now, we apply it to prove Theorem for the following three increasingly more general cases.

Case 1. fff is a simple function on (Ω,σ(S))(\Omega, \sigma(\mathcal{S}))(Ω,σ(S)).

Case 2. f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 and is σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S) measurable.

Case 3. fff is measurable and integrable.

Remark: this follows exactly the same order with which we define Lebesgue integrals.

Case 1. Suppose that f(x1,…,xk)=∑i∈[n]ci⋅IEi(x1,…,xk)f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k)f(x1​,…,xk​)=∑i∈[n]​ci​⋅IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​) is a simple function on (Ω,σ(S))(\Omega, \sigma(\mathcal{S}))(Ω,σ(S)).

  1. For fixed x1:k−1∈Ω1:k−1x_{1 : k - 1} \in \Omega_{1 : k - 1}x1:k−1​∈Ω1:k−1​, according the lemma, the functions fx1:k−1(i)(xk)≐IEi(x1,…,xk),i∈[n]f_{x_{1 : k - 1}}^{ (i) } (x_k) \doteq \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k), i \in [n]fx1:k−1​(i)​(xk​)≐IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​),i∈[n] are Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable.
    It follows that function fx1:k−1(xk)=∑i∈[n]ci⋅fx(i)(xk)f_{x_{1 : k - 1}} (x_k) = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot f_x^{ (i) } (x_k)fx1:k−1​​(xk​)=∑i∈[n]​ci​⋅fx(i)​(xk​) is Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable.

  2. For each ℓ∈[k−1]\ell \in [k - 1]ℓ∈[k−1], since gℓ(i)(xℓ)≐∫Ωℓ+1…∫ΩkIEi(x1,…,xk)d μk…d μℓg_\ell^{(i)} (x_\ell) \doteq \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_k \ldots d\, \mu_\ellgℓ(i)​(xℓ​)≐∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk​​IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ​ is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable, so is the function

gℓ(xℓ)=∑i∈[n]ci⋅gℓ(i)(x1,…,xk). g_\ell (x_\ell) = \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot g_\ell^{(i)} (x_1, \ldots, x_k). gℓ​(xℓ​)=i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅gℓ(i)​(x1​,…,xk​).

  1. Since ∫ΩIEi(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIEi(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1\int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu = \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1}∫Ω​IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​,

∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=∑i∈[n]ci⋅∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIEi(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=∑i∈[n]ci⋅∫ΩIEi(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ω∑i∈[n]ci⋅IEi(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ωf(x1,…,xk)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} &\int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ =& \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ =& \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot \int_{\Omega } \mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu \\ =& \int_{\Omega } \sum_{i \in [n]} c_i \cdot\mathbb{I}_{E_i} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu \\ =& \int_{\Omega } f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ====​∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅∫Ω​IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​∫Ω​i∈[n]∑​ci​⋅IEi​​(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​∫Ω​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​.​

Case 2. Suppose that f≥0f \ge 0f≥0 and is σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal{S})σ(S) measurable.
Then there exists simple, nonnegative functions f(n)↑ff^{ (n) } \uparrow ff(n)↑f.

  1. For fixed xk∈ΩKx_k \in \Omega_Kxk​∈ΩK​.
    The functions fx1:k−1(n)(xk)≐f(n)(x1,…,xk)↑fx1:k−1(xk)≐f(x1,…,xk)f_{x_{1:k - 1}}^{ (n) } (x_k) \doteq f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \uparrow f_{x_{1:k - 1}}(x_k) \doteq f(x_1, \ldots, x_k)fx1:k−1​(n)​(xk​)≐f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)↑fx1:k−1​​(xk​)≐f(x1​,…,xk​).
    Since they are Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable, so is fx1:k−1(xk)f_{x_{1:k - 1}} (x_k)fx1:k−1​​(xk​).

  2. For each ℓ∈[k−1]\ell \in [k - 1]ℓ∈[k−1], let gℓ(n)(xℓ)≐∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωkf(n)(x1,…,xk)d μk…d μℓg_\ell^{(n)} (x_\ell) \doteq \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_k \ldots d\, \mu_\ellgℓ(n)​(xℓ​)≐∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk​​f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ​.
    We prove by induction that 0≤gℓ+1(n)(xℓ+1)↑gℓ+1(xℓ+1)0 \le g_{\ell + 1}^{(n)} (x_{\ell + 1}) \uparrow g_{\ell + 1} (x_{\ell + 1})0≤gℓ+1(n)​(xℓ+1​)↑gℓ+1​(xℓ+1​).
    The claim is true when ℓ+1=k\ell + 1 = kℓ+1=k.
    Next, if this is true for ℓ+1\ell + 1ℓ+1, we show that it is true for ℓ\ellℓ.
    By monotone convergence theorem:

    lim⁡ngℓ(i)(xℓ)=lim⁡n∫Ωℓ+1gℓ+1(n)(xℓ+1)d μℓ=∫Ωℓ+1gℓ+1(xℓ+1)d μℓ=gℓ(xℓ). \begin{aligned} \lim_n g_\ell^{(i)} (x_\ell) &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} g_{\ell + 1}^{(n)} (x_{\ell + 1}) d\, \mu_\ell \\ &= \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} g_{\ell + 1} (x_{\ell + 1}) d\, \mu_\ell = g_\ell (x_\ell). \end{aligned} nlim​gℓ(i)​(xℓ​)​=nlim​∫Ωℓ+1​​gℓ+1(n)​(xℓ+1​)dμℓ​=∫Ωℓ+1​​gℓ+1​(xℓ+1​)dμℓ​=gℓ​(xℓ​).​

    Hence gℓ(n)(xℓ)↑gℓ(xℓ)g_\ell^{(n)} (x_\ell) \uparrow g_\ell (x_\ell)gℓ(n)​(xℓ​)↑gℓ​(xℓ​).
    Since they are Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable, so is gℓ(xℓ)g_\ell (x_\ell)gℓ​(xℓ​).

  3. Since g1(n)(x1)↑g1(x1) g_1^{(n)} (x_1) \uparrow g_1 (x_1) \,g1(n)​(x1​)↑g1​(x1​), ∫Ω1g1(n)(x1)d μ1=∫Ωf(n)(x1,…,xk)d μˉ \int_{\Omega_1} g_1^{(n)} (x_1) d\, \mu_1 = \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu \,∫Ω1​​g1(n)​(x1​)dμ1​=∫Ω​f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​, and f(n)(x1,…,xk)↑f(x1,…,xk)f^{(n)} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \uparrow f(x_1, \ldots, x_k)f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)↑f(x1​,…,xk​), by monotone convergence theorem,

∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=lim⁡n∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf(n)(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=lim⁡n∫Ωf(n)(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ωlim⁡nf(n)(x1,…,xk)d μˉ=∫Ωf(x1,…,xk)d μˉ. \begin{aligned} &\int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &= \lim_n \int_{\Omega } f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } \lim_n f^{ (n) } (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ​∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=nlim​∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=nlim​∫Ω​f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω​nlim​f(n)(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​.​

Case 3. Suppose that f(x1,…,xk)f(x_1, \ldots, x_k)f(x1​,…,xk​) is a measurable and integrable function on Ω\OmegaΩ, i.e., ∫Ω∣f(x1,…,xk)∣d μˉ<∞\int_{\Omega } |f(x_1, \ldots, x_k)| d\, \bar \mu < \infty∫Ω​∣f(x1​,…,xk​)∣dμˉ​<∞.
Write f(x1,…,xk)=f+(x1,…,xk)−f−(x1,…,xk)f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) = f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) - f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k)f(x1​,…,xk​)=f+(x1​,…,xk​)−f−(x1​,…,xk​), such that f+(x1,…,xk),f−(x1,…,xk)≥0f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k), f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \ge 0f+(x1​,…,xk​),f−(x1​,…,xk​)≥0 are measurable and integrable.

  1. For a fixed x∈Ωkx \in \Omega_{k}x∈Ωk​, since both fx1:k−1+(xk)≐f+(x1,…,xk), fx1:k−1−(xk)≐f−(x1,…,xk)f^+_{x_{1:k - 1}}(x_k) \doteq f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k),\, f^-_{x_{1:k - 1}}(x_k) \doteq f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k)fx1:k−1​+​(xk​)≐f+(x1​,…,xk​),fx1:k−1​−​(xk​)≐f−(x1​,…,xk​) are Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​ measurable, so is the function fx1:k−1(xk)≐f(x1,…,xk)=f+(x1,…,xk)−f−(x1,…,xk)f_{x_{1:k - 1}} (x_k) \doteq f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) = f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) - f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k)fx1:k−1​​(xk​)≐f(x1​,…,xk​)=f+(x1​,…,xk​)−f−(x1​,…,xk​) is Fk\mathcal{F}_kFk​.

  2. Since f+(x1,…,xk),f−(x1,…,xk)≥0f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k), f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \ge 0f+(x1​,…,xk​),f−(x1​,…,xk​)≥0 are measurable and integrable, we have

    ∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf+(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=∫Ωf+(x1,…,xk)d μˉ<∞,∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf−(x1,…,xk)d μk …d μ1=∫Ωf−(x1,…,xk)d μˉ<∞. \begin{aligned} \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} = \int_{\Omega } f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu < \infty, \\ \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} = \int_{\Omega } f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \bar \mu < \infty. \end{aligned} ∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=∫Ω​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​<∞,∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=∫Ω​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​<∞.​

    It follows that ∃Aℓ⊆Fℓ\exists A_\ell \subseteq \mathcal{F}_\ell∃Aℓ​⊆Fℓ​, s.t., μℓ(Aℓ)=0\mu_\ell (A_\ell) = 0μℓ​(Aℓ​)=0 for each ℓ∈[k−1]\ell \in [k - 1]ℓ∈[k−1], and gℓ+(xℓ)≐∫Ωℓ+1−Aℓ…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf+(x1,…,xk)d μk…d μℓg_\ell^{+} (x_\ell) \doteq \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1} - A_\ell} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^{+} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_k \ldots d\, \mu_\ellgℓ+​(xℓ​)≐∫Ωℓ+1​−Aℓ​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ​ and gℓ−(xℓ)≐∫Ωℓ+1−Aℓ…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf−(x1,…,xk)d μk…d μℓg_\ell^{-} (x_\ell) \doteq \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1} - A_\ell} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^{-} (x_1, \ldots, x_k) d\, \mu_k \ldots d\, \mu_\ellgℓ−​(xℓ​)≐∫Ωℓ+1​−Aℓ​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμℓ​ are finite on Ωℓ∖Aℓ\Omega_{\ell} \setminus A_\ellΩℓ​∖Aℓ​.
    Define

    gℓ(xℓ)={gℓ+(xℓ)−gℓ−(xℓ),if xℓ∈Ωℓ∖Aℓ0,if xℓ∈Aℓ. g_\ell (x_\ell) = \begin{cases} g_\ell^{+} (x_\ell) - g_\ell^{-} (x_\ell), & \text{if } x_\ell \in \Omega_{\ell} \setminus A_\ell \\ 0, & \text{if } x_\ell \in A_\ell \end{cases}. gℓ​(xℓ​)={gℓ+​(xℓ​)−gℓ−​(xℓ​),0,​if xℓ​∈Ωℓ​∖Aℓ​if xℓ​∈Aℓ​​.

    Then gℓ(xℓ)g_\ell (x_\ell)gℓ​(xℓ​) is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable.

  3. We have

∫Ω1−A1…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1=∫Ω1−A1…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf+(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1−∫Ω1−A1…∫Ωk−1−Ak−1∫Ωkf−(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1=∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf+(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1−∫Ω1…∫Ωk−1∫Ωkf−(x1,…,xk) d μk …d μ1=∫Ωf+(x1,…,xk) d μˉ−∫Ωf−(x1,…,xk) d μˉ=∫Ωf+(x1,…,xk)−f−(x1,…,xk) d μˉ=∫Ωf(x1,…,xk) d μˉ. \begin{aligned} &\int_{\Omega_{1} - A_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &= \int_{\Omega_{1} - A_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &- \int_{\Omega_{1} - A_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1} - A_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &= \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &- \int_{\Omega_{1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \mu_{k} \, \ldots d\, \mu_{1} \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \bar \mu - \int_{\Omega } f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f^+(x_1, \ldots, x_k) - f^-(x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \bar \mu \\ &= \int_{\Omega } f (x_1, \ldots, x_k) \, d\, \bar \mu. \end{aligned} ​∫Ω1​−A1​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=∫Ω1​−A1​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​−∫Ω1​−A1​​…∫Ωk−1​−Ak−1​​∫Ωk​​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​−∫Ω1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμk​…dμ1​=∫Ω​f+(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​−∫Ω​f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f+(x1​,…,xk​)−f−(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​=∫Ω​f(x1​,…,xk​)dμˉ​.​

□\square□

Proof of the Lemma

We restate the lemma, with slightly different notations.

Proving that for each E∈σ(S)E \in \sigma(\mathcal{S})E∈σ(S), and each ℓ<k\ell < kℓ<k,

Let L⊆σ(S)\mathcal{L} \subseteq \sigma(\mathcal{S})L⊆σ(S) be the collection of EEE for which the conditions hold.

  1. Clearly it holds that S⊆L\mathcal{S} \subseteq \mathcal{L}S⊆L; for each(×i=1kAi)∈S\big( \times_{i = 1}^k A_i \big) \in \mathcal{S}(×i=1k​Ai​)∈S, and each ℓ∈[0 . .k−1]\ell \in [0 \, . \, . k - 1]ℓ∈[0..k−1], it is easy to verify that

  2. We show that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ system.

Then since S\mathcal{S}S is a π\piπ system, via Dynkin’s π−λ\pi-\lambdaπ−λ theorem, L\mathcal{L}L is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, and hence L=σ(S)\mathcal{L} = \sigma(\mathcal{S})L=σ(S).

It remains to verify that L\mathcal{L}L is a λ\lambdaλ-system.
Since Ω\OmegaΩ is σ\sigmaσ-finite, we can suppose without loss of generality that μ(Ω)<∞\mu(\Omega) < \inftyμ(Ω)<∞.

  1. Ω∈L\Omega \in \mathcal{L}Ω∈L.

  2. If E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L, we want to prove that Eˉ∈L\bar E \in \mathcal{L}Eˉ∈L.
    In particular, we need to show that Eˉ\bar{E}Eˉ satisfies the equations for each ℓ\ellℓ by induction.

    Base Case: ℓ=k\ell = kℓ=k. This case has been verified.

    Inductive Case: ℓ<k\ell < kℓ<k.
    To prove that gEˉ,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ)g_{\bar{E}, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell)gEˉ,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​) is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable, our goal is to prove that

    gEˉ,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ)=∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIEˉ(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1=μℓ+1:k(×i=ℓ+1kΩi)−∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIE(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1=μℓ+1:k(×i=ℓ+1kΩi)−gE,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ). \begin{aligned} g_{\bar{E}, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell) &= \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{\bar{E}} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \\ &= \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} ) - \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \\ &= \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} ) - g_{E, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_{\ell}). \end{aligned} gEˉ,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​)​=∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IEˉ​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​=μℓ+1:k​(×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​)−∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IE​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​=μℓ+1:k​(×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​)−gE,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​).​

    The measurability immediately follows from the one of gE,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ)g_{E, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_{\ell})gE,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​).

    First, by inductive hypothesis, we have

    ∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIEˉ(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1=μℓ+1:k((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1∘yℓ), \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{\bar{E}} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} = \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( (\bar{E})_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} ), ∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IEˉ​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​=μℓ+1:k​((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​),

    where x1:ℓ−1∘yℓ≐(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ)x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell \doteq (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell)x1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​≐(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​).
    Next, it is easy to verify that

    (Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1∘yℓ=×i=ℓ+1kΩi−Ex1:ℓ−1∘yℓ. (\bar{E})_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} = \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} - E_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell}. (Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​=×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​−Ex1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​.

    By the assumption that μℓ+1:k(Ωℓ+1×⋯×Ωk)<∞\mu_{\ell + 1 : k}(\Omega_{\ell + 1} \times \cdots \times \Omega_{k}) < \inftyμℓ+1:k​(Ωℓ+1​×⋯×Ωk​)<∞,

    μℓ+1:k((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1∘yℓ)=μℓ+1:k(×i=ℓ+1kΩi−Ex1:ℓ−1∘yℓ)=μℓ+1:k(×i=ℓ+1kΩi)−μℓ+1:k(Ex1:ℓ−1∘yℓ). \begin{aligned} \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( (\bar{E})_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} ) &= \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} - E_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} ) \\ &= \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} ) - \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( E_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} ). \end{aligned} μℓ+1:k​((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​)​=μℓ+1:k​(×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​−Ex1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​)=μℓ+1:k​(×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​)−μℓ+1:k​(Ex1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​).​

    Since E∈LE \in \mathcal{L}E∈L, it holds that

    μℓ+1:k(Ex1:ℓ−1∘yℓ)=∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIE(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1, \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( E_{x_{1:\ell - 1} \circ y_\ell} ) = \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1}, μℓ+1:k​(Ex1:ℓ−1​∘yℓ​​)=∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IE​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​,

    which proves the claim.

    Finally, since μℓ:k(Ωℓ×⋯×Ωk)<∞\mu_{\ell: k} (\Omega_{\ell} \times \cdots \times \Omega_{k}) < \inftyμℓ:k​(Ωℓ​×⋯×Ωk​)<∞, integrating over yℓy_{\ell}yℓ​ gives

    ∫Ωℓ∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIEˉ(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1 d μℓ=∫Ωℓμℓ+1:k(×i=ℓ+1kΩi) d μℓ−∫Ωℓ∫Ωℓ+1…∫Ωk−1∫ΩkIE(x1,…,xℓ−1,yℓ,zℓ+1,…,zk) d μk … d μℓ+1 d μℓ=μℓ:k(×i=ℓkΩi)−μℓ:k(Ex1:ℓ−1)=μℓ:k((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1). \begin{aligned} &\int_{\Omega_{\ell}} \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{\bar{E}} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \, d\, \mu_{\ell} \\ &= \int_{\Omega_{\ell}} \mu_{\ell + 1 : k} ( \times_{i = \ell + 1}^k \Omega_{i} ) \, d\, \mu_{\ell} - \int_{\Omega_{\ell}} \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \, d\, \mu_{\ell} \\ &= \mu_{\ell : k} ( \times_{i = \ell}^k \Omega_{i} ) - \mu_{\ell: k} (E_{x_{1:\ell - 1}}) \\ &= \mu_{\ell : k} ((\bar{E})_{x_{1: \ell - 1}}). \end{aligned} ​∫Ωℓ​​∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IEˉ​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​dμℓ​=∫Ωℓ​​μℓ+1:k​(×i=ℓ+1k​Ωi​)dμℓ​−∫Ωℓ​​∫Ωℓ+1​​…∫Ωk−1​​∫Ωk​​IE​(x1​,…,xℓ−1​,yℓ​,zℓ+1​,…,zk​)dμk​…dμℓ+1​dμℓ​=μℓ:k​(×i=ℓk​Ωi​)−μℓ:k​(Ex1:ℓ−1​​)=μℓ:k​((Eˉ)x1:ℓ−1​​).​

  3. If En∈L,n∈N+E_n \in \mathcal{L}, n \in \mathbb{N}^+En​∈L,n∈N+ is a disjoint sequence of sets, then ∪n≥1En∈L\cup_{n \ge 1} E_n \in \mathcal{L}∪n≥1​En​∈L.

    Base Case: ℓ=k\ell = kℓ=k.
    Then gE,x1:k−1(yℓ)=IE(x1,…,xk−1,yk)=∑n≥1IEn(x1,…,xk−1,yk)=∑n≥1gEn,x1:k−1(yℓ)g_{E, x_{1:k - 1}} (y_\ell) = \mathbb{I}_E (x_1, \ldots, x_{k - 1}, y_k) = \sum_{n \ge 1} \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x_1, \ldots, x_{k - 1}, y_k) = \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n, x_{1:k - 1}} (y_\ell)gE,x1:k−1​​(yℓ​)=IE​(x1​,…,xk−1​,yk​)=∑n≥1​IEn​​(x1​,…,xk−1​,yk​)=∑n≥1​gEn​,x1:k−1​​(yℓ​).

    Inductive Case: ℓ<k\ell < kℓ<k.
    The fact that En∈LE_n \in \mathcal{L}En​∈L implies that gEn,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ)g_{E_n, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell)gEn​,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​) is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable.
    By monotone convergence theorem,

    \begin{align*} g_{E, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell) &= \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \\ &= \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \sum_{n \ge 1} \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} g_{E_n, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell). \end{align*}

    Hence, gE,x1:ℓ−1(yℓ)g_{E, x_{1:\ell - 1}} (y_\ell)gE,x1:ℓ−1​​(yℓ​) is Fℓ\mathcal{F}_\ellFℓ​ measurable.
    Applying monotone convergence theorem again,

    \begin{align*} &\int_{\Omega_{\ell}} \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \, d\, \mu_{\ell} \\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \int_{\Omega_{\ell}} \int_{\Omega_{\ell + 1}} \ldots \int_{\Omega_{k - 1}} \int_{\Omega_{k}} \mathbb{I}_{E_n} (x_1, \ldots, x_{\ell - 1}, y_\ell, z_{\ell + 1}, \ldots, z_k ) \, d\, \mu_k \, \ldots \, d\, \mu_{\ell + 1} \, d\, \mu_{\ell}\\ &= \sum_{n \ge 1} \mu_{\ell:k} ( (E_n)_{x_{1:\ell}}) \\ &= \mu_{\ell + 1:k} (E_{x_{1:\ell}}). \end{align*}

□\square□
